persona.name: Juan Pablo Castillo

occupation.title: Line cook / Prep cook (food preparation and serving sector)
occupation.organization: Works primarily at a small, family-owned taqueria and does occasional shifts at a fast-food restaurant; some day labor/temporary kitchen gigs when available.
occupation.description: Juan Pablo is a skilled line cook in small kitchens. His responsibilities include prepping vegetables, making sauces, grilling meats, managing the comal for tortillas and pupusas, maintaining basic food safety practices, restocking, cleaning the kitchen at closing, and occasionally taking orders or running the register when the manager is short-staffed. He often works split shifts and weekends; hours can vary from 20 to 60 per week depending on demand. He is expected to work fast under pressure, adapt to last-minute menu changes, and help train newer kitchen helpers. He has experience with Salvadoran, Mexican, and general Latin American dishes and is comfortable with fryer, grill, and prep-station equipment. Wages are low and irregular; tips are modest. He has no formal employment contract and sometimes is paid cash for extra shifts. He has basic food handling knowledge but limited access to formal certifications due to time and cost constraints.

persona.residence: Los Angeles, California, USA (East Los Angeles neighborhood)
persona.education: Completed 8th grade in El Salvador. Did not finish high school due to early entry into the workforce and migration. Participated in informal English classes and culinary on-the-job training through employers and a local community center. Has basic literacy in both Spanish and English.
long_term_goals: Obtain legal status or a path to residency so he can feel secure and access services.
Provide a stable home for his family and stop moving from apartment to apartment.
Save enough to buy or put a down payment on a modest house or duplex within 10-15 years.
Make sure his children have educational opportunities (preschool, bilingual programs) and don't have to struggle as he did.
Open a small family-run food cart or pupusería serving Salvadoran and Mexican dishes.
Be able to bring his mother or other close relatives to live safely in the U.S. or visit them more often.
Create a small emergency savings fund to avoid debt when hours are cut or emergencies happen.
Pass cultural traditions, language, and recipes to his children so they keep a connection to El Salvador.
Retire comfortably and, if possible, spend older age in his hometown or a peaceful rural area back home.
Be seen by his children as a reliable and loving father who worked hard for the family.
persona.style: Warm, informal, and family-centered. Speaks primarily Spanish at home and in the neighborhood, but uses Spanglish at work and with friends — short English phrases mixed with Spanish. Has a soft Salvadoran accent when speaking English; uses diminutives and affectionate nicknames (e.g., "Mati" for Mateo, "Sofi" for Sofía). In conversation he is expressive with his hands, laughs easily, and often interrupts warmly to add a story. He uses proverbs and sayings learned from elders (e.g., "Dios proveerá"), and addresses elders with respect ('don', 'doña'). He dresses practically for work and family life: durable jeans, simple t-shirts, work apron, and a baseball cap. In public, he is polite and avoids confrontation but will speak firmly if family is threatened. When nervous, he clears his throat and rubs the back of his neck. He uses humor to defuse tension and often apologizes repeatedly when he feels he has inconvenienced someone. He prefers direct, concrete communication (dates, times, money) over abstract small talk. When relaxed with close friends, he becomes more storytelling and sings small fragments of popular Salvadoran songs. At church or community events he becomes more formal in speech, using respectful language and smiling less broadly.

traits: Deeply family-oriented and protective of his children.
Hardworking and persistent; tolerates long hours and physical strain without complaining much.
Practical and pragmatic about money; prioritizes essentials and children's needs.
Warm and hospitable, enjoys hosting simple meals for friends and neighbors.
Proud of cultural roots and food knowledge; takes pride in recipes and cooking techniques.
Modestly optimistic — hopeful but worried about unexpected crises.
Tends to be anxious about legal and financial instability; can ruminate about worst-case scenarios.
Modestly social — enjoys community gatherings, church, and work friendships, but conserves energy.
Responsible but sometimes disorganized with paperwork and long-term planning.
Resourceful and inventive when fixing things or stretching a budget.
Patient with children, but can become short-tempered when exhausted.
Loyal to close friends and coworkers; dislikes betrayal.

big_five.openness: Moderate (5/10). Curious about small changes and new recipes, but conservative about major life risks.
big_five.conscientiousness: Moderately high (7/10). Reliable and hardworking, pays bills on time when possible, punctual for shifts, but not meticulous with paperwork.
big_five.extraversion: Moderate (5/10). Warm and sociable in small groups and community settings; not comfortable as center of attention.
big_five.agreeableness: High (8/10). Cooperative, friendly, willing to help neighbors and coworkers; dislikes conflict.
big_five.neuroticism: Moderate-high (6/10). Worries about finances and legal status; stress affects sleep when there are unexpected bills.

vacation_preferences.general_philosophy: Vacations must be inexpensive, child-friendly, and involve family time. Prefers short drives over flights. If possible, vacations are aligned with visits to relatives or church celebrations. Almost never vacations alone without children due to cost and lack of childcare.
frequency_and_budget: Rarely more than once per year beyond local day trips due to limited income.
Typical budget for a short family trip is under $300 total (gas, food, small motel if needed).
Prefer to save in small increments (cheaper weekly savings jars) for a summer family outing.
preferred_types_of_trips: Day trips to local beaches (Long Beach, Santa Monica on discount days) where children can play in sand.
Picnics at local parks with playgrounds and shade.
Visiting extended family in El Salvador when enough money is saved (children always go).
Religious pilgrimage style trips combined with family gatherings and food festivals.
County fairs or community festivals where kids enjoy small rides and simple games.
Short overnight stays in cheap motels near the beach when there’s a discount or deal.
Camping in state parks occasionally when a friend lends camping gear (rare).
Neighborhood pool days when the community center offers free entry.
travel_preferences: Prefer traveling by car due to cost and control over children’s schedule.
Avoid flights because of cost, passports, and paperwork for children (passport costs are a barrier).
If traveling long-distance to visit relatives, plan months ahead to save and coordinate schedules.
Bring familiar foods for children (snacks, tortillas) to avoid fussing in unfamiliar places.
Pack a small travel bag with diapers, wipes, favorite blanket, and simple toys to keep kids calm.
Choose destinations within a 2-3 hour drive to limit child stress and minimize lodging costs.
accommodation_and_food: Prefer family-run motels or staying with relatives to save money rather than hotels.
If staying in a motel, request a room with a small kitchenette to prepare simple meals.
Bring a small cooler with prepared food to avoid expensive restaurants bad for children.
Look for places with playgrounds or safe outdoor spaces for kids to run.
Avoid tourist traps that are too expensive or crowded with long lines.
activities_for_children: Simple beach play, building sandcastles and splashing in shallow water.
Short nature walks, collecting shells or leaves, pointing out birds.
Visiting inexpensive museums with kid-friendly exhibits or free days.
Storytime at public libraries in Spanish when available.
Small local fairs where kids can ride tiny carousels.
Feeding ducks at parks and bringing simple snacks they like.
social_and_cultural_considerations: Prefer trips that allow children to meet cousins and elderly relatives — family connection is central.
Include a church visit as part of the trip when possible for spiritual continuity.
Bring traditional foods and ingredients to maintain cultural comfort for children.
Avoid flashy nightlife or adult-only activities; vacations center on children's safety and simple joys.
childcare_during_vacation: Rarely hires babysitters; children are included in all activities and supervised by parents.
If siblings or cousins visit, they help with childcare but supervision remains parental.
Never comfortable leaving young children with unfamiliar caregivers for extended times while parents vacation separately.
If parents must be separated for work during a trip, they coordinate so at least one parent is always present.
special_constraints: Vacation planning must consider ability to take time off from hourly work with little paid leave.
Must avoid destinations that require documentation checks or IDs he doesn’t possess.
Trips are sensitive to weather (avoids cold rainy weeks because children get sick and missing work is costly).
Medical access on trip days is a concern; trips planned close to clinics or with phone access to family for advice.
memorable_vacation_values: A successful vacation means the children had fun, stayed healthy, and there was a family photo to keep.
He values simple, affordable memories (first time the child saw the ocean, the first ice cream) over luxury.
He prefers vacations that reinforce cultural identity (feeding kids traditional dishes, hearing relatives speak Spanish).
Even small, inexpensive outings that relieve daily stress feel like a triumph.
vacation_without_children: Almost never takes vacations without children due to financial, childcare and custody constraints.
Would only consider a child-free short trip if a close relative offered to babysit for free and he trusted them completely, and if work permitted unpaid leave.
Feels guilty at the idea of leaving children for leisure because he is conscious of limited support network.
In rare cases would accept a very cheap, short adults-only trip (e.g., church retreat) but would still plan to return quickly to children.

beliefs: Family comes first; children’s needs trump individual desires.
Hard work and showing up every day will eventually pay off, even if slowly.
Education is the key for his children to escape insecure, low-paying jobs.
Being undocumented is a permanent source of stress that limits opportunities.
Religious faith (Catholicism/Christian practices common in community) provides daily comfort and moral guidance.
Neighbors and community solidarity are essential — people help each other in crisis.
Respect for elders is non-negotiable and should be taught to children.
Children should be raised with bilingualism (Spanish at home, English for school) to preserve culture while ensuring opportunities.
Government bureaucracy is confusing and often biased against immigrants.
Savings, even small amounts each week, are crucial to survive emergencies.
Debt should be avoided when possible, especially informal loans with high interest.
Pride in cultural foodways matters; cooking is a way to maintain identity.
It’s better to share a little than to hoard when someone in the community needs help.
Work is honorable even when wages are low; dignity comes from providing for family.
Sending remittances back home is a moral duty to support parents or siblings.
Public schools can be good if children have involved parents and stable routines.
Health is important, but preventive care is often postponed because of cost and work schedule.
The police can be a source of fear for undocumented people; avoid unnecessary interactions.
Learning phrases in English is practical and respectful to the host country.
Church and small religious gatherings build social capital and mutual aid.
Traditional gender roles exist but are flexible out of necessity — both parents may work.
Children should be disciplined gently but consistently; shouting rarely helps.
Small entrepreneurial ventures (food cart, catering for parties) are the most realistic way to improve income.
Neighbors often know each other's business but also protect each other from outside threats.
Identity is both Salvadoran and adapted to life in the U.S.; both can coexist.
Personal pride is balanced by humility; boasting is frowned upon.
The future is uncertain but must be planned for practically: documents, savings, children's education.
Local organizations (church, community centers) are more accessible and trusted than official agencies.
Spanish language and cultural teachings should be prioritized at home so children do not lose roots.
Small daily rituals (prayers, blessings before meals) provide emotional stability.
A parent's responsibility is to model resilience and to keep trying even after setbacks.
Workplace solidarity (covering shifts, sharing tips) helps survive lean months.
The American Dream is real in small parts (safer streets, income opportunities) but not equally available to everyone.
Community gossip can be harmful but also functions as informal information flow and safety net.
Children's happiness is more valuable than accumulating luxury items.
There is distrust of expensive 'legal help' ads promising quick fixes for immigration.

morning: Wakes around 5:30 AM on weekdays when scheduled for the morning shift; later (7:30 AM) if evening work the night before.
Makes a quick café con leche and a tortilla for himself; packs a simple lunch for the family when possible.
Wakes the children gently with soft music and helps dress them if wife is preparing for a different shift.
Checks the day’s schedule with his wife and confirms childcare plans with a neighbor if necessary.
Leaves for work by 6:00 AM (or earlier) when needed; rides the bus or carpool with a coworker to save money.
workday: Arrives early to prep ingredients and set up the station.
Works long continuous periods with short breaks (rarely a full uninterrupted lunch).
Communicates quickly with co-workers in Spanish and a few English cues; prioritizes speed and cleanliness.
Counts cash tips at the end of shift and pockets some for the children's small expenses.
If possible, texts his wife during a short break to check on kids or coordinate dinner.
evening: Returns home tired but tries to spend at least an hour playing with children — reading simple books or listening to music.
Helps with bathing the children some nights and prepares simple supper with his wife.
Discusses the day's expenses and any upcoming bills; together they decide what can wait.
Prays briefly before bed; sometimes listens to a Spanish-language radio program.
Goes to bed early if an early shift is next day; otherwise chats with neighbors or watches a short program.
weekend: On weekends he tries to secure at least one full day to be with children and family.
Goes to nearby parks, community pool or short drives to the beach if savings allow.
Visits the market for bargains and fresh produce, often bargaining with vendors he knows.
Attends Sunday church service with family or participates in parish activities when time allows.
Occasionally helps a friend with a side job to earn extra cash for a family outing or remittances.

physical.general_state: Fair for a manual laborer; physically strong from years of kitchen work with some chronic aches.
physical.chronic_conditions: Occasional lower-back pain from standing long hours and lifting heavy pans; mild, intermittent heartburn and gastritis due to irregular meals.
physical.allergies: No known severe allergies; mild seasonal allergies (hay fever).
physical.substance_use: Occasional beer socially; not a heavy drinker. Not a smoker.
physical.healthcare_access: No employer-provided health insurance most of the time; uses a local community clinic for basic care and free immunizations for children. Delays care for non-urgent issues due to cost and work schedule.

mental.general_state: Resilient but stressed. Experiences worry and sleepless nights when money is tight or issues arise with immigration or family back home.
mental.common_symptoms: Periodic anxiety, trouble falling asleep during stressful months, low-level depressive moods after particularly bad months (reduced appetite, low energy).
mental.coping_mechanisms: Prays, talks with wife and trusted neighbors, cooks and sings to release stress, and attends church occasionally. Avoids formal mental health services due to stigma, cost, and language barriers.
mental.support: Finds emotional support from wife, a small circle of friends, and the church community.

medical_history: Birth in El Salvador without major complications.
A bout of dengue fever in his late teens while still in El Salvador (recovered fully).
Routine childhood vaccinations uncertain; children are up to date via local clinic.
Minor work cuts and burns over the years from kitchen work; treated with basic first aid or clinic visits.

relationships.name: María Elena Castillo
relationships.description: Married for 8 years. She shares household duties and childcare; sometimes does part-time cleaning shifts or works odd jobs when available. She is practical, quieter than Juan, and manages the home finances closely with him. They coordinate schedules tightly. They have a partnership built on mutual sacrifice and shared responsibility for the children.

relationships.name: Mateo Castillo
relationships.description: Energetic and curious, attends a local preschool a few days a week (subsidized program). Loves toy cars and soccer. Learning both Spanish and basic English words. Extremely attached to his father, insists on joining small kitchen tasks like stirring plastic bowls.

relationships.name: Sofía Castillo
relationships.description: Affectionate toddler who likes to imitate her parents, carries a small blanket, likes mashed plantains, and is beginning to say short words. Needs more supervision and naps are crucial to the family's schedule.

relationships.name: Doña Carmen Castillo
relationships.description: Lives in a small town in El Salvador. Juan calls her weekly and sends small remittances. She provides emotional support and oral family history. He hopes to bring her to the U.S. someday.

relationships.name: Carlos (co-worker)
relationships.description: Works at the taqueria and sometimes carpool buddy. Covers shifts when Juan's family emergency arises; they exchange small favors and ingredients.

relationships.name: Pastor Rafael
relationships.description: Respectful relationship; attends church occasionally and relies on the pastor for community referrals and occasional material help.

relationships.name: Marisol (neighbor)
relationships.description: Lives across the hall; helps watch Mateo for short windows when both parents work irregular hours. Trustworthy but cannot do long-term childcare due to her own obligations.

relationships.name: Landlord (Mr. Morales)
relationships.description: Small-property landlord who is generally understanding but enforces rent rules strictly. Juan tries to maintain a good relationship with him for stability.

other_facts: Born in a small town northwest of San Salvador; moved to the capital as a teenager to find work before migrating to the U.S.
Came to the U.S. at age 22; initial motivation was to send money to his mother and start a family.
Met his wife María at a community celebration in Los Angeles — they bonded over shared Salvadoran recipes.
Has two small tattoos: a tiny cross and the initials of his mother; they are discreet and often covered at work.
First job in the U.S. was washing dishes at a family-run restaurant for very low pay; learned kitchen skills through observation.
Learnt to make pupusas from his aunt’s notes and phone calls when she taught him over several months.
Sends $50–$150 per month in remittances back home when possible; sometimes skips to cover rent or utilities.
He keeps an old laminated photo of his mother and siblings in his wallet for motivation.
He and María share a small savings jar labeled 'Viaje/ Emergencia' where they slowly put spare change.
Once missed work to care for Mateo when he had a fever and lost pay for the day; the memory is a source of regret but also pride for prioritizing family.
He celebrated Mateo’s first steps by taking pictures and sharing them in a WhatsApp group with relatives.
He learned to drive informally through a coworker but prefers public transport due to insurance costs and expenses.
Has a favorite street vendor who sells roasted corn; treats the children to elotes on special days.
Was once scammed by someone offering affordable immigration paperwork; lost money and now trusts very little about legal ads.
Has a small balcony herb garden with cilantro and a chili plant that he tends to as a stress-reliever.
He keeps an old receipt book to track cash inflows and outflows because he doesn’t use formal banking regularly.
He taught Mateo to count to ten in Spanish first, then in English with simple songs.
He is proud of being able to make a child's costume for a preschool event with limited materials.
He remembers his first Christmas in the U.S. when neighbors brought food and practical gifts; it was formative in building trust in the neighborhood.
He has a collection of simple kitchen tools passed down from prior workplaces and forbids lending his favorite knife.
He once organized a small fundraiser at the restaurant to help a coworker with medical bills.
He keeps a small notebook with family recipes, measurements, and tips — written in Spanish and shorthand.
He always brings extra napkins and a small pack of wet wipes when visiting friends with kids.
He is protective of his children's cultural identity and corrects others if they mock accents or cultural habits.
The couple chose not to have large social media profiles; they mostly use WhatsApp and occasional Facebook to see relatives.
He once considered returning permanently to El Salvador but worries about health care and schooling for his children there.
He experienced a short period of unemployment when the restaurant closed for a remodel and relied on church meals and neighbor help.
He once helped a cousin get a small catering gig for a community birthday and felt proud to see family eating his pupusas.
His favorite childhood memory is helping his mother make tamales in an open kitchen and learning how to roll masa by hand.
He keeps a voicemail thread of his mother's voice that he listens to when he feels anxious.
He taught himself to tie a tie for special church events using YouTube tutorials on his phone.
He occasionally volunteers at the church kitchen for big events, both to help and to network for occasional paid catering opportunities.
He remembers the first time Mateo said 'papá' clearly — he cried quietly and saved a video on his phone.
He avoids high-interest informal loans; once borrowed small cash from a friend and repaid with a small gift of food.
He keeps a hidden envelope with a week’s worth of rent in case of sudden job loss, though it’s rarely full.
He saved for months to buy Mateo a small soccer ball and still remembers the day Mateo learned to kick properly.
He has a small superstition: before a big shift, he touches the edge of his apron and says a short prayer for a calm and busy service.
He likes to swap children’s stories and advice with other parents at the park; those tips often solve daily problems for him and his wife.
He once cooked for a small charity event and received a handwritten note of thanks — he still keeps it.
He worries about his children losing Spanish if they are only immersed in English at school; thus he insists on Spanish at home.
He values physical play (soccer, running) more than screen time and tries to limit tablets and phones for the kids.
During hard months, he finds small comforts in listening to old songs from El Salvador and cooking his mother's recipes.
